DataElement.preferredName: Lumpectomy Surgical Margin Re-Excision Performed Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether a surgical procedure to remove the remaining abnormal tissues from the edge or border of the tissue removed resulting from a lumpectomy, surgical removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor and some of the lymph nodes under the arm, was performed

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a surgical procedure to remove the remaining abnormal tissues from the edge or border of the tissue removed resulting from a lumpectomy, surgical removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor and some of the lymph nodes under the arm, being performed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The removal of a cancer as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the tumor. Usually some of the lymph nodes under the arm are also taken out.  Also called segmental mastectomy.:The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.:A surgical procedure to remove the remaining abnormal tissues from the body, not completely removed in an earlier attempt.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a discrete mass.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
A surgical procedure to remove the remaining abnormal tissues from the body, not completely removed in an earlier attempt.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.
